noun.description: An attempt to deceive someone into believing that one can or will do something.
examples: the offer was denounced as a bluff

verb.description: Try to deceive someone as to one's abilities or intentions.
examples: the object is to bluff your opponent into submission
he bluffed his way onto an Antarctic supply vessel

adjective.description: Direct in speech or behavior but in a good-natured way.

phrases: she was tempted to call his bluff, hardly believing he'd carry out his threat
In effect, where polluters had previously argued that emission control was too expensive, the new system called their bluff.
Right or wrong, some of the guards called their bluff, and we can learn from that.
I think furiously, she's calling my bluff, I'll push even further
And should it respond by accommodating its demands, or by calling its bluff?
origin: Early 17th century (as an adjective, originally in nautical use): of unknown origin.
